description: Borrowed from Ancient Greek φίλανδρος (phílandros, “loving men”), from φιλία (philía, “love”) and ἀνδρός (andrós), genitive case of ἀνήρ (anḗr, “man”).

examples: Yes, I'll baste you together, you and your Philander!

entries.meaning: A South American opossum, bare-tailed woolly opossum, Caluromys philander, formerly Didelphis philander.
An Australian bandicoot, greater bilby or bilby, Macrotis lagotis, formerly Perameles lagotis.

verbs.description: philander (third-person singular simple present philanders, present participle philandering, simple past and past participle philandered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To woo women; to play the male flirt.
examples: You can't be philandering after her again.
